measured_by: declining to look at the cost of helping before making the Helping Game decision
justification: The authors state that Player A could either ‘look’ at the precise cost or decide ‘without looking,’ and that this latter choice constituted an “uncalculating decision.”

measured_by: amount of money Player B sends to Player A in the Trust Game
justification: The article notes that “Player B’s sending reflects their trust,” linking the sum sent in the Trust Game to the construct of trust.

measured_by: percentage of the tripled amount that Player A returns to Player B in the Trust Game
justification: The text explains that “Player A’s returning reflects their trustworthiness,” so the return rate operationalizes the actor’s trustworthiness.
The paper describes a follow-up study that “operationalized ‘uncalculating’ decision-making as deciding quickly, rather than with limited information,” identifying rapid choice as the measurement.

measured_by: binary choice to pay cost c to deliver 2c to a third-party in the Helping Game
justification: Player A “decided whether to incur cost c to deliver 2c to a third-party (i.e., to ‘help’),” making the help/not-help decision the behavioral measure of prosocial helping.
